texts.text: My vision clears, and I find myself face to face with myself once more.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So it's over?

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: No, that was just the beginning. You still have a lot of time to experience, now that you have experienced the awakening signal.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: We were pretty innocent back then, huh? Both of us.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I wouldn't have imagined Yonagi was ever such a bright and lively girl.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: Yes. She was bright and true. She always knew what true happiness really was, even if it took me a little time to figure that out.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: On the other hand, I was a pretty wimpy kid.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: Once we started living together, we looked out for each other. All the other lowsiders watched over us.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: Looking back on it, I think we were lucky to have such a supportive community behind us.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: I was just too young to realize it back then.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: But as you can imagine, we grew up.

texts.name: Kaito (Hologram)
texts.text: We made it to adulthood, together.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: *Huff*! *Huff*!
Finally!
It's the day I—
No, the day we've been waiting for all these years.
I run along the trail through the cornfields.
I wonder how many times I've walked down this path during all these years.
They looked so tall back when I was a kid, but now they're about eye level.
And yet I run down this road the same way I always have.
I dash like I did when I was a kid, pure joy fueling my steps.
The house comes into view at the end of the long trail.
Our house.
Yonagi is waiting for me in there.
I can't wait for her to hear the good news so we can celebrate.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yonagi!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Kaito, welcome back! What happened to you? Were you running?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's been decided!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hm?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm going to start working in Professor Asuma's lab! I'll be an associate researcher!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: *Gasp*!
Yonagi gasps, her eyes widening in surprise.
Seeing the exact reaction I was expecting brings a huge smile to my face.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You did it! Congrats!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's all thanks to you. We need to celebrate!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You bet we will! Let's make something special today! Izumo deserves a rest anyway!
I put my bag down and sit at the table.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Here.
Izumo quickly places a bowl of boiled flakes on the table.
It's the same dish Izumo makes for us every day.
My gaze meets Yonagi's, and we can't help but smile.
It's been more than ten years since Mom passed away and we started living together.
I started attending college, and now I've been selected as a research student candidate. Thankfully, I was assigned to my first choice of workplace, Professor Asuma's lab.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The current big idea is developing new drugs for oral intake, but I don't believe that research will go anywhere.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Or rather... It excludes too many.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: They'll never be able to make a drug that's 100\% safe for everyone. And right now, only the young and healthy will be able to experience life on the surface.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Professor Asuma's solution can help a lot more people.
Yonagi smiles and nods along with my rapid explanation.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We're one step away from becoming midsiders. We won't have to work down here anymore.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Midsiders, huh?
Yonagi's gaze wanders down to the table as she murmurs.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Aren't you happy?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I'm really happy you're achieving your dream!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: But I really like our home here.
Her gaze drifts to the bed by the window.
The sunset light seeping through the window gives the empty bed an orange hue.
I know what she must be imagining right now.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: ...I love this house too. We have a lot of memories here. But we have to move forward.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We need to live.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yeah, I know.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If we go to the middle side, we won't have to work every day. You can use the time to write your novel.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I'm happy working during the day then having dinner together like this. I mean, you'll still be working during the day as a researcher, right?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, but...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Writing is more of a hobby for me, so I'm happy doing it in my free time. I'm fine with us both working, and then spending our evenings together.
She smiles fondly at me.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: But I'm really happy for you! You can't even imagine!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You've always wanted to work with Professor Asuma, right?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I haven't seen him in so long. Has he been well?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah. He pretty much looks the same as back when we were at school.
We started living together right after Mom passed away.
Me, Yonagi, and Izumo.
Before being dumped like trash, Izumo had her data wiped and some of her functions disabled.
It seems like the topsiders don't like their androids being reused, so they intentionally ruin their functionality before throwing them away.
It took a long time to repair the damage they had done to her.
I still haven't managed to fix her completely, either.
The fact that she cooks the exact same thing every day must mean there are still some things not quite sorted out inside of her.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Thanks for the meal.
When I finish my meal and put the spoon down, Izumo begins to clean the table.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Thanks, Izumo. It was delicious.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Glad to hear.
There's only room for one table in our tiny house.
At each mealtime, I have to shelve my terminals and research materials, then get them back out after we're done.
I've always wanted the space for at least one more desk.
Moving to the middle side would solve all that.
Just the thought of it makes my heart leap.
Yonagi places several books on the table along with a hardcover notebook and a pen, and sits across from me.
Every night she writes her stories down in that thick notebook.
I believe she's writing a story about William Shakespeare right now.
She's always liked his stories, ever since we were kids.
It's hard to believe that even after humanity fled underground, we're still reading something some Western guy wrote eight centuries ago.
I doubt Shakespeare himself could have even imagined such a thing back in his time.
After dinner, we each do our own thing until bedtime.
I continue my research while Yonagi reads and writes.
It's a quiet, joyful time.
There's nothing better than spending our time together in the same space as we work on our own different projects.
It's a habit we fell into soon after we started living together.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I wonder what kind of person he was...
About a hour and a half into her reading, Yonagi murmurs to herself, seemingly in deep thought.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Shakespeare?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Good question.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I imagine he was popular with the ladies.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What makes you say that?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: He captures the woman's heart so well! It's kind of, like, poethic!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Poethic.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: He writes about so many different things. It's honestly kind of intimidating.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Really? How so?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It feels almost like one human couldn't possibly have written this. Like it has to be the work of many people or something.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Maybe he just had a good memory like me.
There's an unnatural silence after that. I look up from my research.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Oh, I see! So he was able to write about so many things because he remembered the stories of the people in his life so well?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Uh, it's not like I knew the guy.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: No one does. The records of his time are pretty vague. Though that does have its upsides.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Really?
Yonagi nods and raises a finger to her chin.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What do you mean?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It gives me some creative freedom to... embellish the details a little. Or a lot.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see. So if you were to seriously argue that Galileo Galilei or Isaac Newton were actually women, nobody could tell you that you were wrong.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Maybe so!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That does sound like an interesting story.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So if Shakespeare was the kind of guy who never forgets a story once he hears it...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Then wouldn't he need to be in a position where he talks with lots of different people?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So like a teacher or something?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That would probably be too limiting.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Professors may talk to many people, but they're usually younger, and the age range is limited.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It sounds like I need to do some research on old England.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That sounds like a plan.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You're starting work at the institute tomorrow, right? Maybe I can swing by the library when I'm done with work tomorrow. It's been a while since I last visited.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Sounds good. Let's meet up there.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yeah! We haven't been to the library together in forever.
She turns back to the book in her hand, looking pleased.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: ...Wanna do it today?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mhm.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Okay.
Yonagi closes the book and holds out her hand.
Mom's looking out the window.
It's her.
I try calling out, but sadly...
No sound comes out of my mouth.
She just keeps looking out the window.
Her chest slowly moves up and down in time with her breathing.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: No luck?
I shake my head.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hmm...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No dice, huh?
Yonagi has the power to conjure up and share images with others.
I started calling the world she creates the "dreamscape."
Mom started appearing in it shortly after we started living together.
I believe it might have something to do with the first time when Yonagi and I shared strong emotions.
It was the first time anyone else had appeared in her dreamscape.
Before that, all she could show was her own memories and the characters she'd created.
But...
Despite my mom being right there, we can't communicate.
I'm merely a spectator in the space Yonagi creates.
I'm still searching for a way to actually interact with her dreamscape.
I feel frustration at being unable to reach out to Mom when she's right in front of me.
But it only serves to fuel my desire to study and find a solution.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Izumo, could you show our brain waves?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: I will begin monitoring them.
I compare our brain waves after entering the dreamscape.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: How can we make it so you can talk in there?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I really don't know. It's not like there are any precedents for this.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And I don't have the power to project mental images like you do.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mhm, mhm.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I think if we're able to reproduce a faux dreamscape, and maybe convey my thoughts to you in real time, it could work.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Right now, my perception of myself talking isn't being received by your mind at all.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I think that's why I can't interact with your dreamscape.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The communication only goes one way.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hmm. So what do we do?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Synchronize something we both have.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Like our brainwaves, maybe. For example, when you have a fun conversation with someone close to you, the frequency and amplitude of your brainwaves start to synchronize.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Whoa!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But I still don't have any way to transmit them to you...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Man, this whole science thing sure is tough, huh?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Okay!
I pack my stuff into the bag I've been using since I was a kid, and hang it over my shoulder.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm ready.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Right! I'll come to the institute after I'm done with work, okay?
I nod in response.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Have a good day.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I'll try! Do your best, my junior researcher!
She sees me off with a bashful smile on her face.
She does this every morning, without fail.
And I remember each and every one of her smiles.
It wasn't until I started living with Yonagi that my inability to forget things began to seem like not such a bad thing after all.
I go up the elevator to the middle side and head to the institute.
I find myself staring at the researchers' living quarters located behind the main building.
Anyone who becomes a full researcher gets to live there, and can commute to work in just minutes.
My pace slows as I imagine myself walking to work from one of those buildings.
I wouldn't have to clean dirt off my shoes every day.
No more worrying about the cornfield sprinkler schedule whenever we want to go out.
I could give Yonagi a better life. We could be together in one of those big houses.
As I daydream, I notice a familiar face walking along from the living area to the square.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: Morning, Kaito.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Good morning.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: And so we meet on the very first day of our new life as researchers. I can't help but wonder if it's fate that's brought us together this fine morning.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Maybe it has to do with the fact we're both going to the same place.
He catches up to me and we walk together to the institute.
I first met Iruma in an engineering course for research candidates.
He's a born midsider and his father is a researcher as well. He's always been pretty friendly, though.
While all the other midsider research candidates held me in clear contempt for being a lowsider, Iruma was the only one to speak to me like a human being.
I remember one of the first things he said to me after I explained my situation: "Whoa, how did you manage to study with all the work you lowsiders have to do? You must be a genius."
It was kind of a rude thing to say, but I could tell he wasn't trying to be mean at all.
He wasn't trying to make fun of me for being a lowsider. He was genuinely impressed by the fact that I'd managed to accomplish something in such difficult circumstances.
Ever since then, he’s been the only person I could call my friend in the workplace.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: You got assigned to Asuma's lab, right?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And you're with Kano, yeah?
I heard that the lab Iruma applied for got the most applications this year.
That'd be Kano lab. They're at the forefront of the study of drugs that can improve UV ray resistance, and that's the subject of research that's more predominant in the institute right now.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: What's Professor Asuma researching, even?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The virtual space, same as he's always done. That's why I chose him.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: Oh, I remember that. I didn't know there were labs still looking into that.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's just him. That's why I didn't have much choice.

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: So you care about what you research, huh? I guess when you're valedictorian you start to care about that stuff.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You don't care about what you work on?

texts.name: Iruma
texts.text: You know I'm just killing time with this whole thing. I just picked the one that would let me socialize with other people the most. It has a lot of people working on it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Heh, always the same, aren't you?
The walls and floors are all white and uniform.
This place has always doubled as both the city's research facility and its educational institution.
Until just yesterday, I was a student here.
But starting today, I stand here as a researcher.
...A junior one, but my job is the same.
I stop in front of the door to Asuma's lab and take a deep breath.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: ...You're ready.
When I take a step forward, the door slides open automatically, and I see Professor Asuma sitting at a desk in the back of the room.
The light seeping through the blinds illuminates no one but him in the lonely lab.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Good morning.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Hm? Oh...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I've been assigned to your lab as a junior researcher.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Ah, I see. That's today, is it?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes.
He directs a jovial smile at me.
Then he swivels on his chair to face me.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: As you might imagine, not many junior researchers want to be assigned here. It's been a while since we had a newcomer.
I notice a hint of self-derision in his dry chuckle.
I decide not to say anything for now.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Which brings me to my question. Why choose this lab?
He looks up at me, and I can feel the curiosity in his gaze.
I slowly take a breath before answering.
This is something I've wanted to tell him for years.
I feel like I've been waiting for this day ever since I first heard of his work.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Your vision resonates with me, Professor.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: My vision?
I nod decisively.
He stays seated, his gaze urging me to elaborate further.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Humanity shares a common goal in migration to the surface, but the challenges it entails are far too complex.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The primary issue is the problem of ensuring safety against exposure to UV rays.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: One approach is to prevent contact with the UV rays themselves, while others propose increasing the body's resistance to them.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If humanity migrates back to the surface, we'll be spreading out over a much wider area. Increasing the body's resistance is the only option.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I see. You're absolutely right. And right now, they're working on oral medicine that can do just that.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: They're attempting to remedy the effects of paraglucose on our physiology, and get us to a state where we can walk on the surface again.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Should it succeed, no external equipment such as the ozone lens will be necessary. It solves the problem at its very core.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Wouldn't you have preferred to work on something like that?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Even if they were to succeed...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The second issue is the suitability of the environment on the surface.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We don't know what the surface is like right now. Even if it's habitable, there's still the problem of deciding who lives where, and how you're even going to decide who makes those decisions.
The professor gives me a level stare.
I decide to keep going with my explanation.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What I mean to say is that a full-scale migration to the surface will take a huge amount of time. Three decades at the least, or even more.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Life in the underground is too harsh to endure for that long.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: In particular... for the people in the low side.
He raises one eyebrow upwards at that remark.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: You...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm a lowsider.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I see.
I nod in response.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Sorry for interrupting. Please continue.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But with your virtual space migration model...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We could live on the surface virtually while we waited for the migration to take place in real life.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It would only have to be temporary. But I believe having a temporary respite until a real solution is reached would be well worth it.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: But you don't believe the virtual space would be that real solution.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Feel free to speak your mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Not right now, no.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But I want to make a difference that I can see while I'm still alive.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I want to know that I changed things.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I don't want to be just a gear in some grand plan that will span across generations. I want to see change happen in this world.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: While I still draw breath.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Your youthful enthusiasm is commendable.
He lets out a small chuckle.
I don't detect any negativity or maliciousness in his tone.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: And your name is...
The professor glances down at his desk and pulls a piece of paper out of the pile.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Aha, Kaito. I see.
I nod once more.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Well, you've made your point most eloquently. I'm sure that, after all the thought you've put into it, you are aware of the state of this lab.
I'm nodding a whole lot today.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Research these days is trending towards developing UV protective measures. Sixty percent of the laboratories in this facility are working towards that goal.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Most of the research is aimed at producing oral intake tablets that could temporarily alter our physiology to be closer to that of the old humans.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: The majority of people and resources are being used to that end.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Honestly, there are not many, other than myself, who are interested in my research.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Despite all that, you want to work here with me, do you?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Follow me. I'll give you a rundown of where we're currently at.
He gets up from his chair and strides to the back of the lab.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: In short, my design currently has an essential flaw. For the moment, anyway.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It does?
He nods.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Have you ever entered a virtual space?
No one knows about Yonagi's power but us.
I can't tell anyone about it.
I don't even know if Yonagi's dreamscape could be called a virtual space.
So it's not like I'm lying.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: This is not cutting-edge technology by any means. In fact, what I'm doing is digging up obsolete technology from the old world.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: This technology was popular on the surface, once. But that was a century ago.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Obsolete? You mean the technology that simulates the virtual space?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Well, seeing is believing. Give it a whirl.
The professor motions for me to sit down in a capsule-like chair then fishes a small orange case from his chest pocket. He produces a pill from it and presents it to me.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: This is drug to artificially induce REM sleep. Nothing harmful for you, just a slightly more potent sleeping pill.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Its effect is immediate and its duration short. You can suck it or chew it, whichever you prefer.
I take the pill from his outstretched palm.
Then I pop it into my mouth and feel it melt across my tongue.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's... sweet.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Now lean back in the chair and close your eyes.
I do as instructed, and...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Whoa...

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: This is a simulation of Kanagawa prefecture in the year 2016. Look around. You can even enter the building.
I head towards the curious building in front of me.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Where are you?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I'm still in the lab. I'm monitoring the sensory information in your thalamus from out here.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: You should be able to move around normally.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You're right.
I can even speak.
It feels similar to Yonagi's dreamscape.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What is this place?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: An old educational facility from that time. Quite extravagant, is it not?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah.
The facility is furnished with a massive library, a hall, and countless classrooms.
It's humongous compared to my idea of a place of education.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: How did you like that short excursion to the surface?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It was... incredible.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Let's go back. I'll brew you some coffee.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Coffee?
The professor grinds some kind of black grain into a fine powder using a machine, and then filters water through it to produce a black liquid.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: It's merely roasted corn mixed with artificial caffeine. It's one of the first things that was ever developed in this facility.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I've read about it, but I've never tried it.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: It's meant to keep you from getting drowsy. Real coffee plants that grew on the surface naturally contained caffeine.
I bring the mug to my lips and take a mouthful.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's pretty bitter.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: The day you come to enjoy the taste is the day we can call you a true researcher.
He says as raises his cup to his lips as well.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Now, did you figure out the biggest flaw of the virtual space on that little trip?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Was that space indistinguishable from reality?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I think so?
He watches me, a smile playing across his lips.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Give it a good think. You were able to stay for about thirty minutes, but there's a reason why you wouldn't be able to stay there all day. And that would be...
I recall my experience in the virtual space.
I could move as naturally as I can in the real world.
The temperature felt right.
I could feel the ground beneath my feet.
I could even hear my footsteps.
After a moment of reflection, I finally realize.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The smell. There was no scent.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Exactly.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Now I get it. If you're simulating the virtual space by manipulating the thalamus, then...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You can't control any sensory data that doesn't run through the thalamus.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The sense of smell doesn't really use the thalamus, therefore...
I mutter to no one in particular as I recall the things I learned when I looked into Mom's condition.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: You really know your stuff, huh?
He looks genuinely surprised by my familiarity with the topic.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: You are absolutely right. And with that knowledge, you should be able to figure out why it's such a fatal design flaw.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If the sensory feedback inside of the virtual space is realized by the external use of the thalamus...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Then you'd need an entirely new approach to recreate the sense of smell.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Exactly. A world that lacks one of the five senses isn't a world fit to live in.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: This approach has reached a dead end.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So we need to think of an entirely new fundamental theory.
He gives me a solemn nod.
I wonder about Yonagi's dreamscape.
Does it have any smell?
I've never thought about it before now.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Not all of my research so far would be wasted, of course. The simulation data of all my subjects so far can be used to streamline the process of creating patch files to fit each person's individual needs.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: If we weren't able to automate the process at some level, debugging would be the work of a lifetime.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Right now, I'm looking for a new way to approach the project. Though I guess fumbling in the dark would be a more appropriate way to put it.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Of course, as your advisor, I'll teach you everything I know.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: But in this lab, you and I are equals. We start by sharing ideas, and working towards the same goal.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Let me warn you, though: you might spend your entire life drinking this bitter coffee and talking until dawn without actually accomplishing anything.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Knowing that, do you still want to work in this lab?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Of course!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'd like nothing more. I didn't expect that I could jump right in to doing cutting-edge research.
Professor Asuma gives me a warm smile.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I feel the same way. Never could I have dreamed of welcoming such an excellent and enthusiastic researcher into this lab.
He gets up and holds out his hand.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Thank you for holding out hope in my research. Let's see this dream through together.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes!
I stand in a hurry, wipe the palm of my hand on my pants, and clasp his hand as firmly as I can.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Welcome to the Asuma lab.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'll do everything I can to find a new way forward for mankind.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: No need to be quite so nervous. We're in this for the long run. Part of your job, starting today, is to enjoy your research.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes!
The professor used the rest of the day to tell me about the various methods he's attempted to further his research and the current avenues he's looking into.
The basic premise of his idea is to directly tamper with a person's brain signals to create almost the same perception as if the body was really moving in the physical world.
The biggest roadblock to this would be...
The inability to secure subjects to test such a thing.
One cannot just perform experiments on humans unless their safety can be guaranteed.
That's why he has no choice but to rely on preexisting research.
Going through the data from when humans lived on the surface, you'll see that in the long history of brain science, there were certain points where rapid advancements were made.
For example, when wars broke out.
Securing corpses with their brains intact must have been easy during times of war.
Or if you found an injured person whose brain was damaged, you could study what role the damaged part played.
As a result, understanding of the brain advanced, and we used this knowledge to make new weapons of war.
It's quite ironic.
In that sense, going underground had a chilling effect on the advance of science.
While life may not be perfect, we live in peace.
This Shinjuku settlement would be more akin to what the surface people would have called a "village" once upon a time.
Though if human history is anything to go by, it's obvious that if there were physical networks linking the underground cities, conflict and wars would break out at some point in time.
As things stand, intentional murder is a rare occurrence here in the underground.
And that's why Asuma lab has hit a snag.
It's quite a somber thought.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hello there, handsome!
Yonagi's cheerful tone pulls me out from my thoughts. I look up to see her waving at me.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: How was your first day as a researcher?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Pretty good, I think.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: That's my boy!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I got here early, so picked up a book to read.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What's it about?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The brain.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You sure like that stuff, huh? You read it all the time.
I nod.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I suppose it's my life's work now. So yeah, I do like it.
Looking up from the book, I smile at Yonagi.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And from now on, it's my job, too.
She gifts me another one of her sweet smiles in response.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I better get lookin' too!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Shakespeare, I presume?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yep! I also need some reference material on what England was like during the surface era.
Now that I'm a junior researcher, I can borrow thirty books at a time.
Any book that multiple researchers would want to reference was digitized long ago, so there's almost no competition for paper books.
I'm sure most of the useful data is available in digital format, but there'll always be things that slip through the cracks.
Back when books were made with paper, paper books were primary sources.
Somebody has to make the decision on what to digitize.
And when information is curated like that, it stops being a primary source at all.
And with my memory condition, I can afford to read more than just the bullet points. It'd be silly not to make the most of it.
I can cram my brain with all the seemingly superfluous information without any drawbacks.
If I'm going to be helping Professor Asuma, I need to have as broad a range of knowledge in my head as possible to help give me ideas during our discussions.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Whoa... So it looks like people ate out a lot in England back in the old days. It wasn't just a Japan thing.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mhm.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Old England had places called pubs where people gathered every night to eat and drink.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mm...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Wha—! Kaito, you gotta hear this!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It says that women couldn't act on stage back then! Why not?!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I couldn't tell you.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You're not even listening to me...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hmm, this is so eye-opening. So this is the world Shakespeare lived in.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Kaito?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mm?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Can I take out a few books too?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Of course.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yay!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I got assigned to replace the water pipes in the west area today.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Huh, that brings back memories. Is the chief doing well?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You don't even know the half of it! He just came back from a dispatch to the power generation area, and he was so happy when I told him about you!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: He's so impressed with you becoming a big fancy doctor!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There's no PhDs anymore though. Only junior researchers and researchers.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Gee, thanks for the history lesson! How much more can you even study? Your head's gonna turn into a literal book.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I hope it doesn't happen anytime soon, because I haven't achieved a thing yet.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm not even close to the finish line.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm... So your thirst for knowledge is unquenchable, huh?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I think that's true for all scientists. The more you learn and widen your horizons, the more you want to know.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Actually, I guess it'd be more apt to say that you're increasingly aware of the things you don't know.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Is it fun?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You keep going because it's fun to learn more, right?
Is it?
I thought about it, but I felt it was different.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No, it's so that someday we can have fun...
I turn to her and gather my thoughts.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm working hard now so we can have a good life together in the future. So we can be happy together.
Yonagi's eyes widen, but then she smiles fondly at me.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I'm having lots of fun right now.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But there's so much more.
As we walk, I look up at the ozone lens.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There's the middle side above us, and above them is the top side. And no one even knows what's out there on the surface.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: As long as I'm with you, I'm happy enough being a lowsider.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But if we lived in the middle side, you'd be even happier. It's just like what I said about knowledge.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm sure we can be happier up there. We just don't know it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's only after we're up there that we'll realize how hard life was down here.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I wonder about that.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Even if that were the case, it doesn't mean that our happiness right now will disappear, will it?
I turn my gaze from the middle side cityscape back to Yonagi.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: First we need to know what life is like there. And soon, we will.
I take her hand in mine and give it a good squeeze.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mhm.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I got some synth milk today.
The mention of milk brings back a memory that makes me chuckle.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If Izumo gets her hands on it we're gonna get boiled milk with corn again.
Yonagi also breaks into a sweet giggle.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Aw, that's fine. She says it's good for digestion!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And the taste of warm milk is calming, too. I've gotten used to it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I suppose our chef does a good job.
We walk to the elevator together, holding hands and talking about our day.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I actually read something interesting today. Apparently there was a dish called porridge in England a long time ago.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Porridge?
She turns to me with a gleam in her eyes.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So you make it by like, mixing milk and boiled grains together into a mush.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Is it any good?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: We eat it all the time!
I suppose corn is a kind of grain.
We do eat it pretty much all the time, and Izumo's idea of mixing things up is just to add hot milk.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Izumo's favorite dish was porridge this whole time, and we didn't even notice!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Hah, that's funny.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I wonder what she'll say when I tell her about it!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: We're back!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Hello there.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Welcome home.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Here's today's rations. Hey, Izumo! I learned that the dish you make for us all the time is called porridge.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Porridge?
Yonagi nods, a satisfied smile on her face.
Izumo glances my way.
While her expression betrays no emotion, I sense an inkling of confusion behind it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Supposedly the dish you make with boiled corn and synth milk is called porridge.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yeah, exactly!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: The one you make all the time! The one you're really good at cooking!

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: I am not good at cooking.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: But your food is delicious! Isn't that right, Kaito?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Huh? Y-Yeah.
Yonagi shoots me a disapproving glance.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I mean, I never get bored of it, and it's not bad. I'd say you're pretty good at it, sure.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Once I made a really awful dish of porridge.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Since it's theoretically possible to make bad porridge, the fact that you make it delicious every time means you're good at making it.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Gosh, what a prince charming.
She lets out an exasperated sigh.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Ignore him, Izumo. Kaito can be like that sometimes.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You're gonna make your best dish tonight, right? I even brought some synth milk.

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: I'll begin preparing at once.
Izumo turns towards the kitchen and begins preparing dinner. Yonagi watches her and smiles.
After finishing dinner and putting away the dishes, Yonagi piles the books on Shakespeare and England she borrowed today up on the table.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yonagi, think you could show me something?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Anything in particular?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The usual. Or any of the worlds you made. Anything.
Is there smell inside Yonagi's dreamscape?
I need to make sure.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Okay, I've got just the thing.
After a moment of deliberation, she extends her hand to me.
I clasp it and close my eyes.
This is a new place.
I look around me.
It's similar to descriptions I've read of old European towns.

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: Well met! Welcome to Tenbridge!
As per usual, I can't speak.
I felt more free in the professor's virtual space.

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: This is the city of Tenbridge, nestled in the heart of England. The city of theater!

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: And my name is Olivia Berry, actress.
I cock my head to the side.

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: What are you looking at?

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: I coined the word, for there is no other that describes one such as me!
Next, I look up at the sky.

texts.name: Olivia (Yonagi)
texts.text: Kaito?
I can feel a faint breeze blowing on my face.
The sky above us is a blanket of blue.
I take a deep breath.
And there it is—a smell.
However...
I let go of Yonagi's hand, and we're back to reality.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It smelled like Shinjuku.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Smell?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yonagi, let me smell you.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Huh? Smell? Why?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'm trying to figure something out.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You want to smell me? Why?!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No, Olivia's.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I need to smell Olivia. I have to.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What? What are you even talking about? You're seriously creeping me out.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's important, Yonagi.
I take her hand again and close my eyes.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hyah?!
I walk up to the transformed Yonagi, cup her cheeks, and bring my face close to hers.
She's giving off a familiar scent.
It's...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It smells like you.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Wh-Wh-What's going on? Did they do something to you at the institute?! Where did you pick up this strange fetish?!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Why does she smell like you?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You're freaking me out! When did you turn into a psycho?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Isn't Olivia supposed to smell more, err, womanly or something?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What?! Now you insult me?!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: *Sniff*
I bring my face close to hers and drink in the scent.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah, it's just you.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I don't think I've ever felt humiliated in this particular way before!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: *Sniff*

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I mean... I don't even know how old England is supposed to smell!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Ah, so that's it. I see...
I let go of Yonagi.
So that place smells like Shinjuku...
...because she doesn't know how the surface smells.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: *Sniff*
Tenbridge didn't smell like this house, but like the lower side.
I couldn't smell Izumo's porridge in there either.
In other words, it didn't smell like the real space we're in right now.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hnnghh!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Mm? What's wrong?
Above her flushed cheeks, tears are pooling in Yonagi's eyes.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Pervert! You researcher with kinky proclivities!
I see now. Since Yonagi hasn't experienced any other scents, Tenbridge defaults to what she knows.
Which means...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And all you're gonna do is smell me? That's it?!
If I expose her to more scents, would that enrich the variety of scents in her dreamscape?
It's an interesting notion, certainly. I think it warrants some testing.
So...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Are you even listening to me?!
There's a high chance that the professor's virtual space and Yonagi's dreamscape are created in completely different ways.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Stop seeing and start listening, would you?!
The next day, I enter the lab and encounter professor Asuma already sitting at his desk.
After learning how to make coffee from him yesterday, I take the opportunity to brew cups for both of us.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Virtual spaces became widely used about 150 years ago.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Research and development of VR-related software and hardware was booming up until the year 2046.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: 2046? Did it suddenly decline in popularity for any particular reason?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Records show that back then, humanity was making use of a large-scale organic telecommunication system. But after the network was hacked, people came to harbor a deep distrust of technology in general.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Organic telecommunication systems, huh?
I've read about that period before.
If I remember right...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The artificial pigeons, right?
The professor nods.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Yes, birds. Creatures that soared in the skies.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So are there still many of those birds on the surface today?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: No. External networks were no longer needed once telecommunications had progressed to their current state. Around the year 2100, all the birds were retired and taken out of service.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Current state... You mean the internal chips?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Exactly. When you have direct connections between people, you don’t need most of the functions a network provides.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And those functions were...?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Information sharing.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Back then, it was all done indirectly. Data was uploaded to and stored in huge central servers that could be accessed when needed.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Now, every single person is a walking communications device, and their own personal data storage vault. Not that anyone is really aware of it.
A huge interconnected server, huh? There's certainly no such thing in Shinjuku. We probably wouldn't have the electricity to power it.
But the biometric chips, the basic intercommunication methods... All that was common in the surface era. So..

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Why are we still using those while the virtual space was abandoned?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: There is no one single reason. But if you think about what we're trying to reproduce with the virtual space right now...
The professor trails off, clearly inviting me to finish the thought.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The surface world.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Yes. A city, the symbol of an advanced civilization. And a natural world where the sun shines down, the wind blows, and the rain falls.
I nod along.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: They had all that on the surface from the start. Why virtually reproduce something you can just walk out of your door to see?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: All the spaces created for the virtual world were ultimately fake. It caught the attention of people for a few decades, but ran its course as fads tend to do.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: It was only after losing the surface and being forced underground that mankind realized the true beauty of nature.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: You really don't know what you have until it's gone. That applies to both women and life.
The professor chuckles at his own comment.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: The virtual space that was created on the surface was but a toy. Despite already living in an ideal world, they sought a paper thin ideal that couldn't stand up to scrutiny.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I remember reading a parable like that once in a book from the surface.
The professor nods, a note of excitement tinging his voice.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Maeterlinck's 'The Blue Bird'. You really are well read.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I've always liked stories.
Or rather, Yonagi does.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So even back then, there were people who realized that the grass always looks greener on the other side.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: A hundred years separate the time Maeterlinck lived in and the development of the virtual space.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: But perhaps there were such people, yes. Like in any era, there were people who mastered technology, people who became slaves to it, and people who hated it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Maybe the ones who mastered it, and the ones who hated it, both had the foresight to understand what you're describing.
The professor nods and takes a sip of his coffee.
After talking with Professor Asuma into the evening, I swing by the workshop.
The printer he used to help me make my car all those years ago is still in the same place.
It brings back so many memories.
I was with Yonagi back then.
Actually, that reminds me—she's been in a sour mood since yesterday night.
But I haven't the faintest idea as to why.
I pray she's in a better mood when I get home.
I need her to help me out again tonight.
I came here to prepare for that, actually.
First of all, I need to print some scents.
I choose some cartridges for the aroma printers and set them up.
The scent of a clear day under the sun. The smell of rain.
Meadows, seas, and forests.
This should cover most natural environments.
And also...
The scents of herbs, flowers, and fruits.
The machine aeresolizes the scents I chose into particles before printing them into small capsules.
I carefully stow the capsules in my bag and leave the institute behind.
All the capsules I printed out clink together inside my bag as I head towards home.
I can't wait to have Yonagi help me today.
I can hardly contain my excitement as the house comes into view.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Welcome home!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Hey there. I need your help tonight.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I don't want to get sniffed again.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Oh, no, you're doing the sniffing today.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What the hell? No way! I don't wanna sniff you!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What are you talking about? You don't need to sniff me.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Where did you get that idea?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Excuse me? Izumo, can you back me up here?!

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: I will prepare dinner.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Why is there not a single soul in this house I can have a proper conversation with?!
After we're done eating Izumo's porridge, I fish out the capsules from my bag and line them up on the table.
I notice that Yonagi's still reading books about 16th century England.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What are those?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Smells from the surface.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Smells...?
I nod enthusiastically.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: This one should smell like a grassy meadow, for example.
I open up the meadow capsule for her.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Whoa! So this is how it smells.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I also have the smell of a city.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Different places have different smells?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Seems so.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Ooh, can I smell the others too?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Sure.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: This is... chamomile? What's that?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: A species of herb that has a strong scent. It was in the first encyclopedia you ever showed me.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yeah?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's a basic herb. You don't remember?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Uh, of course not? How many years ago was that?
Yonagi frowns and squints at me.
The frown turns upside down the next second, so I realize she's not actually mad.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Can I open it?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Go right ahead.
Yonagi takes the capsule and opens it, then bring it closer to her face.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It smells so different! I thought meadows were just full of weeds.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The molecular composition of the two are different. The nasal cavity has about four hundred receptors that perceive different smells by—

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I think I like this smell!
Yonagi declares, a smile lighting up her whole face.
But the olfactory system is so interesting...
Especially how the nasal secretions serve as both protectors and carriers of odor molecules in the nose. The whole topic is so interesting.
...Oh well. Maybe I'll be able to talk about it another day.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That smell is apparently very reminiscent of apples.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I've never even seen fancy fruits like that. I'm no topsider.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I got the smell of apples here if you want to compare.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Ooh!
I open the apple capsule and hand it to her.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: They do smell kinda similar!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So this is what an apple smells like.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I brought the scents of some flowers too. I learned that there was something called perfume on the surface. People used to make scents from flowers and cover themselves in them.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mhm!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: This is so fun! I was definitely creeped out yesterday, but I think I'm starting to see why you developed a smell fetish now.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I don't have a fetish, though?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Didn't you literally sniff me all night yesterday?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And then you bring all these scents home? Now you're gonna tell me that you don't have a weird fixation on smells?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No, in Professor Asuma's virtual space, I...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Oh? Now you change the topic?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No, no! The virtual space has this big flaw. You can't smell anything inside of it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The current method the professor is using involves externally manipulating the thalamus, but most olfactory information isn't processed through the thalamus.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I really can't follow when you start talking about brain stuff.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So you were sniffing me yesterday for research purposes?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Why else would I be?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Kaito, my boy?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yes?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Hearken to my words. I want you to listen real well to what I'm about to say. You know how people are supposed to communicate and say why they do things before actually doing them?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You understand what I'm trying to say, yes?
I nod at her.
Ever since she read a Japanese novel from around the seventeenth century, she's started speaking funny sometimes.
It's weirdly old-timey, but I find it endearing.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And this is hardly the first time we've had this talk, is it?
I shake my head.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Today makes the sixteenth time. I think that's a good stopping point.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: A good stopping point?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's one of the powers of two. A beautiful, almost mystical number.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Well then, you better make sure there isn't a seventeenth time!
I nod in agreement.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Seventeen is a prime number. It only believes in itself, and the number 1. It doesn't get along with the other numbers.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I care not!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Whoa, this smells so nice.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: This is rose. It used to be real popular.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Ooh, so this is the scent Queen Elizabeth liked!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Really?
She bobs her head enthusiastically.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: She loved it enough for people to call her the queen of roses.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It has kind of a refined, lady-like scent. I wonder if Olivia would smell like this.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I imagine rose perfume must have been popular at the time. Not something the common people would've had access to, though.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It's okay! Olivia lives in the house of an aristocrat!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So it would make sense for her to smell fancy like that, yeah?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Yep, I think so.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I never thought about how my characters might smell before, but this really helps me visualize them better.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Now try picking a smell for the town.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: The feeling I get from what I read is that Europe wasn't really a clean place around that time.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: But it doesn't have to be that THAT realistic, right? I think a meadow smell would be nice! Yeah, this one!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: All right.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So, what do I do?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: When you take me to your dreamscape, you show me the world you envision, right?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: First, I want to see if I can smell the scents you put into your world. I'd like to take this step by step.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Step by step, you say.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Let's try a scent that both of us know first.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And then we'll try a scent that only you know. For example...
I pick up one of the capsules and hand it over to her.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: This is the scent of a flower called sweet osmanthus. I don't know how it smells.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Funny name.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I want to know if you can reproduce a scent only you know and transmit it to me accurately.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If you can create the scent in the dreamscape, I can smell it from the capsule afterwards and see if it's the same.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I see. So it's gonna be like a guess the scent game!

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I suppose that's a way to put it.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Sounds fun.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If I can perceive scents in your dreamscape, I might be able to figure out what's going on in my brain when it happens and then reproduce it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It would help the professor's research immensely.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Oh, right. You said his research has kind of fallen by the wayside, right?
I nod.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So I'm doing this for you and Professor Asuma... Okay! Guess I don't mind lending you a hand!

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Kaito?
The scent of wind.
This is it.
The world the professor and I wanted to recreate.
The scent of a wind that doesn't exist in Shinjuku.
Under a bright, blue sky.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It smells so nice.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Wow... I can't believe people used to live in such a beautiful place.
It's hard to explain how much difference adding scents makes.
It makes me feel so free, so immersed in this space.
It's on a whole different level.
Like a literal whole new world.
But I have no time to marvel at it.
Can I reproduce this?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yonagi, how about Olivia?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Ah, right. Okay...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What do you think?
I approach Olivia slowly.
Her scent is just like Yonagi envisioned.
Sweet, rich, and almost dazzling.
I could smell it clearly.
I approach her then take a step back.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: ...I see.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Is something wrong?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No...
The moment you solve one problem, another rears its head.
It's the nature of research.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Okay, what next? Can we go indoors?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Okay.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Did you figure something out?
While I can't answer her question in this space, I have realized something important.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So, did that help?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The concentration of the scent is ignoring the laws of physics.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Smells are made up of particles suspended in the air. They diffuse and move freely through the air in three dimensions.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The concentration of the scent should become weaker in inverse proportion to the cube of the distance it travels.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Uhhh?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But the smells are all uniform inside your dreamscape.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Which means...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The scents inside of your dreamscape are experienced exactly as you envision them in your mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It doesn't take into account how far away they are from the source.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Ah...
Something sticks out to me about what I just said. It feels like two unconnected things are about to connect.
I close my eyes and go back through my memories.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see... We could solve it by...
Data was uploaded to and stored in huge central servers.
I could use what the professor had told me about networks from the old surface era today.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I think I have a new idea. It may even make me able to speak in your dreamscape.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What? I'm really not following you.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Let me explain.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What I'm seeing in your dreamscape right now...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: ... is probably the image you're creating in your mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There's visual feedback, sound, touch, and smell there.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But I'm merely receiving and processing it.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm, right.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That's why smell doesn't work like it's supposed to, because I'm just a spectator.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I never noticed before, but I'm probably even hearing sounds at the same volume I would if I were standing where you were.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It's so obvious in hindsight. No one would bother to think about how the five senses of someone else would perceive the same things.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That's why you have no problem showing me things that exist only in your mind, like the worlds you picture in your novels, for example.
Yonagi looks over her conceptual sketches for a moment.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So does that mean you won't ever be able to speak in there? No matter what we do?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Well...
I ponder for a long moment.
Her dreamscape was unidirectional. If you wanted everyone inside to perceive the actions of a participant...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Oh, there is a way.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But it's not gonna happen.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What do you mean?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The participant would need to have the same power as you.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Then instead of unidirectional transmission, it would be bi-directional. You could each share your mental images to each other in real time, and what might happen is that the two fuse together.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: I see...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But we don't know anyone that may have the same abilities as you. Does such a person even exist?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: If they do, we've never met them.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But this is what I want to do, in essence.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Basically, I want to convert this unilateral dreamscape into a two-way street.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But even this two-way dreamscape is impractical. It can't be generalized.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Generalized?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There's a condition for being able to participate, right? It's only two-way if someone has the same power you do.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: So...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Maybe, instead of communicating your thoughts directly into someone's mind, you could send them to an external server first.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The process you naturally use to send images and sensations to other people must be the same as the process the body uses to send sensory information to the brain, so it should be possible to convert it into electrical signals.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The server could take into account things like the distance between you and me or the nature of the space around us, and use it to make the sensory information work in accordance with real physical laws.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There's lots of libraries for handling physics in virtual spaces, so we won't need to make one ourselves.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Libraries? As in, the one in the institute?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No, it's what we call blocks of code with functions that are commonly used.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If we could set this up, we could use the same system we use to send bio signals to Izumo to transmit brain signals.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I can't send images into people's brains like you can, though.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Do you need to use the biochips for this to work?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Yeah.
Every single inhabitant of this city has a nanochip installed in them that acts as a personal identification and records their biometric data.
But while all lowsiders have them, it doesn't mean they'll receive medical care if the data shows a problem.
It makes me wonder why they even bother in the first place.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And the integrated virtual environment we make together could be shared to other participants using Asuma Lab's current technology.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: If we do use this setup, we could create a dreamscape that can integrate each person's perception, no matter how many people are in the system.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: So if we do this...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: You could talk with Mom again?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It may be possible. If the perception of a particular person is strong enough in all of the participants...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: What does that mean?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That space would no longer be the manifestation of your image alone.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It would become an amalgamation of the perceptions of all the people participating in it.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: In that situation, if we wanted to create an embodiment of a dead person in that space...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It'd need all the participants.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Or almost all of them. You would need enough people with the same image of the person to be able to treat the signals coming from the people who didn't know them as noise that could be discarded.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Like God, perhaps.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: God?
I nod.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: In other words, everyone needs to know who this person is, and have a shared awareness of what they look like and what kind of person they are.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Someone like that, like God, for instance, might be made manifest inside that space.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: A world where God manifests...

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: It sounds kind of romantic, doesn't it?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: For that to happen, though, everyone inside the thought space would have to want them to appear.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Right now, it's just you and me, and we both know mom well. If we both share the same mental image of her...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It could be possible if we figure out this server deal in detail.
I look up.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Think you could do it?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Excuse me?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Send your mental image to a machine.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We'd need to send it to an intermediary server first in order to make it work.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm, I've never tried to do it with anything other than a person.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: And... I kind of don't like the idea of anyone but you looking into what's in my mind, to be honest.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Even if it's a machine?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm...
Yonagi bites on her lower lip as she ponders.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: ...Well, I suppose I wouldn't mind if it was Izumo.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Izumo, huh?

texts.name: Izumo
texts.text: Mm?
I mull over her words for a moment.
Izumo's OS is powerful enough, to be fair.
However, android operating systems have iron-clad security to stop hacking.
That's one of the main reasons I've been unable to restore all the functions that were broken when she was thrown away.
I can't even increase the amount of dishes in her food repertoire.
There's definitely no way I can add in new functions.
We'll need some kind of auxiliary device between us and Izumo.
The only such function of hers that remains is a number calculation process that gives results in response to external input. In other words, she can solve math problems.
Still, her computing power is extremely high.
There isn't a faster or more sophisticated computer than Izumo, at least in the low side.
If we're making an integrated dreamscape, faster processing power will mean less lag.
And with Izumo's power, the delay would be pretty much unnoticeable for our brains.
However...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: By the way.

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Mm?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Why would you be okay with Izumo?

texts.name: Yonagi
texts.text: Well, she's family. I can trust her. Plus, she's cute.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Cute...
So as long as the auxiliary device is cute and feels like family, she's okay with it?
I put my hand up against my forehead.
After a moment of thinking...
I realize that's a tall order.
The next day, Professor Asuma shows up in the lab in the afternoon.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Ah, Kaito. Good day. Sorry, we had a general debriefing today.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Debriefing?
He directs a pleasant smile at me and explains.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: All researchers in the institute are called to a debriefing whenever a remarkable discovery is made.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Well, it's pretty much a presentation to convince the higher ups to assign a bigger budget when the possibility of a breakthrough is found.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Today's debriefing was from a group of researchers developing a type of UV protective agent that is applied to the skin. They were allotted more researchers and budget for their studies.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: More researchers?
The professor's affable expression turns a few shades sadder.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Sorry about that. We used to have more researchers here.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Oh, no, don't apologize.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: While we're on the topic, why don't we take the day to discuss current research trends at the institute? Not like what you read in the monthly journals they release, but what I know from being on the inside.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That'd be great.
We move in front of the lab's digital board to talk.
He speaks of the city's distribution systems, power generation, and storage methods for relics from the surface era, such as clothing.
He tells me about the general lines of research being explored and the city's history with remarkable eloquence and simplicity.
All of this is news to me.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see. So only now are we ready to try and move back to the surface.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: The standard of living here in the underground has finally hit an acceptable level. Back in the surface era, it was always the most advanced countries that set their sights on space.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Shinjuku was the first underground city created in Japan. Thus, we're at the vanguard when it comes to research as well.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But we still don't have any pills that work on UV rays?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: We do, but none of them work that well.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: If anything, they seem to serve as a striking example of the placebo effect.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Oh...

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Why do you believe that is?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Uh...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Back when I was a student, I remember you once showed the class an image of a patient suffering from melanoma.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Ah, that was a primary education lesson, yes? You have quite the memory.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: It terrified me. And I think, at the same time...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Despite knowing the ozone lens was above us, I felt fear at the idea of living in the top side.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That's when I started wondering if the topsiders were doing anything in particular about it. Like taking some kind of medicine just to make sure nothing happened to them.
He says nothing as he sips on his coffee.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: There are various reasons why the people in the top side are fine. First and foremost, the robust construction of the ozone lens.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Since the day we humans moved underground, there hasn't been a single case of a human contracting and dying from melanoma under the ozone lens.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Their safety is perfectly guaranteed. The topsiders especially seem to prefer safety data when it comes in the form of hard numbers.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: There's the matter of education as well. You're a lowsider, right? You must know better than anyone how much better off the topsiders are when it comes to learning opportunities.
I nod back.
While Yonagi and I toiled, they had time to study. There's also a special education curriculum just for them.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: As you say, the topsiders are the ones closest to the sun. In the extremely unlikely event that the ozone lens were to somehow fail or collapse...

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: They would be the first and most numerous victims. That's why the gathering of knowledge is so important for them.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Knowledge to fulfill their role as the topsiders of our city.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Their role?

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: They are the ones who think about the distribution of our limited food and water throughout the city, and it's also their job to make the occasional risky trip to make observations on the surface.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: There are also topsider-only labs that research and develop androids, too.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I see... An android wouldn't have any trouble being exposed to UV rays. So that's why.
Izumo's blank face flashes through my mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I'd like to take a look at those labs they have up there.
The affable smile returns to his face.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: When you're in a position to look into that, you will learn how. That's how this city operates.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Though if we were to look back at the long, twisting labyrinth of human society, you could say that we have been repeating the same pattern for as long as we have existed.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Lowsiders will aim to become midsiders, and midsiders will aim to become topsiders. And in the same way, every person in this city yearns to leave the ozone lens behind.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Despite us having dug our own hole and hidden in it to begin with.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: I'm sure the same would happen to our virtual space in time. One day, inevitably, people will yearn to experience the real, waking surface world. It's easy to picture.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Even I could be simply retracing the same history that humankind has repeated time and time again. In the end, this research may serve to do nothing but satisfy my own ego.
His eyes wander over his desk, his gaze seemingly a thousand miles away.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I don't know about that.
Professor Asuma's gaze focuses on me again.
The memory of my late mother comes to mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: For example, there are people out there who are paralyzed.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Would those people have any reason to want to return to the real world?

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Even if a solution to the UV rays is found, moving to the surface would be difficult for such people.
He simply stares at me as I speak.
His face betrays no emotion whatsoever.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The first thing that struck me about your research was how much kindness I felt from the whole concept. That's what gripped me.

texts.name: Asuma
texts.text: Kindness?

texts.name: Kaito
